elements.content: The reaction of colorless iron(II) formate or the mixed-valence cluster Fe3O(MeCOO)6(H2O)3 with formic acid in dimethylformamide exposed to air at 110 °C affords black crystals of the mixed-valence (Me2NH2)[FeIIFeIII(HCOO)6] three-dimensional (3D) structure in which the cations occupy half of the channels. The structure consists of alternating layers of FeIIO6 [Fe(1)−O(1), 2.119(1) Å] and FeIIIO6 [Fe(2)−O(2), 2.0049(9) Å] octahedra bridged by anti−anti-bonded formates to afford an open-framework 3D structure. The structure is very similar to those of (Me2NH2)[FeII(HCOO)3] and [FeIII(HCOO)3]·HCOOH, both of which are colorless. The black crystals appear dark-purple (λmax ≈ 520 nm) when powdered. The room-temperature Mössbauer spectrum confirms the 1:1 ratio of Fe(II) (δ = 1.03 mm/s, ΔE Q = 1.16 mm/s) and Fe(III) (δ = 0.62 mm/s, ΔE Q = 0.49 mm/s). Magnetic ordering that includes negative magnetization at low fields occurs at low temperature. The only molecular-based magnetic materials in which this phenomenon has been observed are the 2D polyiron(II,III) oxalates A[FeIIFeIII(C2O4)3] (A = R4N+ cation).
elements.clean_text: The reaction of colorless iron(II) formate or the mixed-valence cluster Fe3O(MeCOO)6(H2O)3 with formic acid in dimethylformamide exposed to air at 110 °C affords black crystals of the mixed-valence (Me2NH2)[FeIIFeIII(HCOO)6] three-dimensional (3D) structure in which the cations occupy half of the channels. The structure consists of alternating layers of FeIIO6 [Fe(1)-O(1), 2.119(1) Å] and FeIIIO6 [Fe(2)-O(2), 2.0049(9) Å] octahedra bridged by anti-anti-bonded formates to afford an open-framework 3D structure. The structure is very similar to those of (Me2NH2)[FeII(HCOO)3] and [FeIII(HCOO)3]⋅HCOOH, both of which are colorless. The black crystals appear dark-purple (λmax ~ 520 nm) when powdered. The room-temperature Mössbauer spectrum confirms the 1:1 ratio of Fe(II) (δ = 1.03 mm/s, ΔE Q = 1.16 mm/s) and Fe(III) (δ = 0.62 mm/s, ΔE Q = 0.49 mm/s). Magnetic ordering that includes negative magnetization at low fields occurs at low temperature. The only molecular-based magnetic materials in which this phenomenon has been observed are the 2D polyiron(II,III) oxalates A[FeIIFeIII(C2O4)3] (A = R4N+ cation).

elements.content: The presence of mixed-valence iron(II) and iron(III) imparts important properties to minerals such as magnetite (Fe3O4) and pigments such as Prussian Blue (PB) (FeIII 4[FeII(CN)6]3·xH2O), which has been called the first coordination compound. An extensive body of research in recent years on PB and its transition-metal analogues has been motivated by their properties, including high-temperature molecular magnetism. There is a comparable level of interest in coordination polymers utilizing larger multitopic ligands to obtain larger cavities in open-framework structures, a good portion of which have been obtained using metal carboxylates. Mixed-valence polyiron(II,III) oxalates A[FeIIFeIII(C2O4)3] (A = R4N+ cation) have been shown by Day and co-workers to exhibit Néel N-type ferrimagnetism with some cations but not others. The rare negative magnetization observed in the two-dimensional (2D) polyiron(II,III) oxalates has not been seen in 3D molecular-based network magnets until the present work.
elements.clean_text: The presence of mixed-valence iron(II) and iron(III) imparts important properties to minerals such as magnetite (Fe3O4) and pigments such as Prussian Blue (PB) (FeIII 4[FeII(CN)6]3⋅xH2O), which has been called the first coordination compound. An extensive body of research in recent years on PB and its transition-metal analogues has been motivated by their properties, including high-temperature molecular magnetism. There is a comparable level of interest in coordination polymers utilizing larger multitopic ligands to obtain larger cavities in open-framework structures, a good portion of which have been obtained using metal carboxylates. Mixed-valence polyiron(II,III) oxalates A[FeIIFeIII(C2O4)3] (A = R4N+ cation) have been shown by Day and co-workers to exhibit Néel N-type ferrimagnetism with some cations but not others. The rare negative magnetization observed in the two-dimensional (2D) polyiron(II,III) oxalates has not been seen in 3D molecular-based network magnets until the present work.

elements.content: The reported framework structures of the anionic divalent formates A[MII(HCOO)3] (1) [A = NH4 +, Me2NH2 +, (Me2enH2 2+) 1 /2 ; M = Mn, Co, Ni] and neutral trivalent formates, [MIII(HCOO)3]·X (2) (M = Mn, Fe, Al, Ga, In; X = HCOOH, CO2) are remarkably similar, with cations in the cavities of the former and small neutral molecules such as formic acid or CO2 in those of the latter. This suggests that it should be possible to isolate mixed-valence structures of iron(II) and iron(III) related to PB as well as 3D anionic polymetal(II,III) oxalates.
elements.clean_text: The reported framework structures of the anionic divalent formates A[MII(HCOO)3] (1) [A = NH4 +, Me2NH2 +, (Me2enH2 2+) 1  /2 ; M = Mn, Co, Ni] and neutral trivalent formates, [MIII(HCOO)3]⋅X (2) (M = Mn, Fe, Al, Ga, In; X = HCOOH, CO2) are remarkably similar, with cations in the cavities of the former and small neutral molecules such as formic acid or CO2 in those of the latter. This suggests that it should be possible to isolate mixed-valence structures of iron(II) and iron(III) related to PB as well as 3D anionic polymetal(II,III) oxalates.

elements.content: Reactions of Fe3(HCOO)6·DMF in a combination of DMF and concentrated formic acid afford mixtures of colorless crystals of (Me2NH2)[Fe(HCOO)3] (1) and Fe3(HCOO)6 (orthorhombic form) and black crystals of (Me2NH2)[Fe2(HCOO)6] (3). These have to be mechanically separated. An alternative synthetic approach that affords pure crystalline samples of 3 involves heating the mixed-valence cluster [Fe3O(CH3COO)6(H2O)3] (4) at 110 °C in a mixture of DMF and concentrated formic acid.
elements.clean_text: Reactions of Fe3(HCOO)6⋅DMF in a combination of DMF and concentrated formic acid afford mixtures of colorless crystals of (Me2NH2)[Fe(HCOO)3] (1) and Fe3(HCOO)6 (orthorhombic form) and black crystals of (Me2NH2)[Fe2(HCOO)6] (3). These have to be mechanically separated. An alternative synthetic approach that affords pure crystalline samples of 3 involves heating the mixed-valence cluster [Fe3O(CH3COO)6(H2O)3] (4) at 110 °C in a mixture of DMF and concentrated formic acid.

elements.content: The colorless iron(II) formates encountered in this work are isomorphous to formates of other divalent transition metals. The intensely colored crystals, on the other hand, are unprecedented mixed-valence polyiron(II,III) framework formate materials. Whereas the anionic iron(II) formate 1 crystallizes in the rhombohedral space group R3̅c with Z = 6, compound 3 crystallizes in the trigonal space group P3̅c1 with Z = 2.
elements.clean_text: The colorless iron(II) formates encountered in this work are isomorphous to formates of other divalent transition metals. The intensely colored crystals, on the other hand, are unprecedented mixed-valence polyiron(II,III) framework formate materials. Whereas the anionic iron(II) formate 1 crystallizes in the rhombohedral space group R3̅c with Z = 6, compound 3 crystallizes in the trigonal space group P3̅c1 with Z = 2.

elements.content: There are two independent iron atoms in the asymmetric unit of 3 (Figure ). Bond valence sum (BVS) calculations indicate that Fe(1) is iron(II) (BVS 2.12, FeO6 octahedral volume of 12.6 Å3) and Fe(2) is iron(III) (BVS 3.08, FeO6 volume of 10.7 Å3). The formates bridge each Fe(1) to six different Fe(2) atoms in the anti−anti bonding mode. This results in a structure composed of alternating layers of Fe(II) with Me2NH2 + cations and Fe(III) perpendicular to the unique c axis (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: There are two independent iron atoms in the asymmetric unit of 3 (Figure ). Bond valence sum (BVS) calculations indicate that Fe(1) is iron(II) (BVS 2.12, FeO6 octahedral volume of 12.6 Å3) and Fe(2) is iron(III) (BVS 3.08, FeO6 volume of 10.7 Å3). The formates bridge each Fe(1) to six different Fe(2) atoms in the anti-anti bonding mode. This results in a structure composed of alternating layers of Fe(II) with Me2NH2 + cations and Fe(III) perpendicular to the unique c axis (Figure ).

elements.content: Thermal ellipsoid plot of (Me2NH2)[FeIIFeIII(HCOO)6] (3). The cation is disordered about a D 3 site, and only one N−H···O hydrogen bond is shown. Fe(1)−O(1), 2.119(1) Å; Fe(2)−O(2), 2.0049(9) Å; Fe(1)···Fe(2), 5.89 Å.
elements.clean_text: 1  Thermal ellipsoid plot of (Me2NH2)[FeIIFeIII(HCOO)6] (3). The cation is disordered about a D 3 site, and only one N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bond is shown. Fe(1)-O(1), 2.119(1) Å; Fe(2)-O(2), 2.0049(9) Å; Fe(1)⋅⋅⋅Fe(2), 5.89 Å.

elements.content: Polyhedral representation of the layered structure of 3, with Fe(II) in green, Fe(III) in ocher, and N in blue (only two representative cations are shown).
elements.clean_text: 2  Polyhedral representation of the layered structure of 3, with Fe(II) in green, Fe(III) in ocher, and N in blue (only two representative cations are shown).

elements.content: The structure of 1 is very similar to that of 3 except that there is only one crystallographic iron site and all of the cavities are occupied by Me2NH2 +. The volume and Fe−O bond lengths are 13.0 Å3 and 2.1362 (7) Å, respectively, in the FeIIO6 octahedra in 1 and 10.6 Å3 and 1.997(2) Å, respectively, in the FeIIIO6 octahedra of 2.
elements.clean_text: The structure of 1 is very similar to that of 3 except that there is only one crystallographic iron site and all of the cavities are occupied by Me2NH2 +. The volume and Fe-O bond lengths are 13.0 Å3 and 2.1362 (7) Å, respectively, in the FeIIO6 octahedra in 1 and 10.6 Å3 and 1.997(2) Å, respectively, in the FeIIIO6 octahedra of 2.

elements.content: The 3D network in 3 consists of Fe(III) surrounded by an octahedral arrangement of six nearest-neighbor Fe(II), while six Fe(III) form a trigonal prism about each octahedral Fe(II). The Fe···Fe distances are 6.04 Å in 1, 5.89 Å in 3, ∼5.5 Å in [FeIIFeIII(C2O4)3]−, and 5.08 Å in PB. The 2D and 3D polymetal oxalates have only three neighboring metals.
elements.clean_text: The 3D network in 3 consists of Fe(III) surrounded by an octahedral arrangement of six nearest-neighbor Fe(II), while six Fe(III) form a trigonal prism about each octahedral Fe(II). The Fe⋅⋅⋅Fe distances are 6.04 Å in 1, 5.89 Å in 3, ~5.5 Å in [FeIIFeIII(C2O4)3]-, and 5.08 Å in PB. The 2D and 3D polymetal oxalates have only three neighboring metals.

elements.content: The observed parameters in the room temperature (298 K) Mössbauer spectrum of 3 (Figure ) support the structural data and are indicative of high-spin Fe(II) and Fe(III) with oxygen coordination. The magnetic susceptibility data (Figure ) indicate that Fe(II) and Fe(III) are noninteracting at room temperature but that spontaneous magnetization occurs at low temperature, including negative magnetization that has been seen in only Day and co-workers’ anionic polyiron(II,III) 2D magnets.
elements.clean_text: The observed parameters in the room temperature (298 K) Mössbauer spectrum of 3 (Figure ) support the structural data and are indicative of high-spin Fe(II) and Fe(III) with oxygen coordination. The magnetic susceptibility data (Figure ) indicate that Fe(II) and Fe(III) are noninteracting at room temperature but that spontaneous magnetization occurs at low temperature, including negative magnetization that has been seen in only Day and co-workers' anionic polyiron(II,III) 2D magnets.

elements.content: Room-temperature Mössbauer spectrum (hatched marks) of powdered crystals of 3. The spectrum can be decomposed into two components, with Fe(II) in green [isomer shift (δ) = 1.03 mm/s, quadrupole splitting (ΔE Q) = 1.16 mm/s, line width (Γ) = 0.31 mm/s] and Fe(III) in ocher (δ = 0.62 mm/s, ΔE Q = 0.49 mm/s, Γ = 0.30 mm/s). The black solid line is the composite spectrum.
elements.clean_text: 3  Room-temperature Mössbauer spectrum (hatched marks) of powdered crystals of 3. The spectrum can be decomposed into two components, with Fe(II) in green [isomer shift (δ) = 1.03 mm/s, quadrupole splitting (ΔE Q) = 1.16 mm/s, line width (Γ) = 0.31 mm/s] and Fe(III) in ocher (δ = 0.62 mm/s, ΔE Q = 0.49 mm/s, Γ = 0.30 mm/s). The black solid line is the composite spectrum.

elements.content: Plot of χM T vs T for powdered crystals of 3.
elements.clean_text: 4  Plot of χM T vs T for powdered crystals of 3.

elements.content: The black crystals, which appear dark-purple when powdered, exhibit a very broad intervalence charge-transfer (IVCT) band (λmax ≈ 520 nm ≈ 19 200 cm−1) that covers the whole visible spectrum (Figure S1 in the ) and a more intense peak at 280 nm. The intense color is bleached when the material is dissolved in water or DMF. The polyiron(II,III) oxalates do not exhibit an IVCT band, although Lippard and co-workers’ valence-delocalized diiron(II,III) paddlewheel carboxylates do (Fe···Fe 2.7 Å). The physical properties of this framework material indicate class II mixed-valence behavior in the Robin−Day classification scheme.
elements.clean_text: The black crystals, which appear dark-purple when powdered, exhibit a very broad intervalence charge-transfer (IVCT) band (λmax ~ 520 nm ~ 19200 cm-1) that covers the whole visible spectrum (Figure S1 in the ) and a more intense peak at 280 nm. The intense color is bleached when the material is dissolved in water or DMF. The polyiron(II,III) oxalates do not exhibit an IVCT band, although Lippard and co-workers' valence-delocalized diiron(II,III) paddlewheel carboxylates do (Fe⋅⋅⋅Fe 2.7 Å). The physical properties of this framework material indicate class II mixed-valence behavior in the Robin-Day classification scheme.

elements.content: Synthetic details, UV−vis and IR spectra, and thermogravimetric and X-ray powder diffraction data for 3 and details of the crystal structures of 1 and 3 (CIF). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

The polyiron(II,III) oxalates do not exhibit an IVCT band, although Lippard and co-workers’ valence-delocalized diiron(II,III) paddlewheel carboxylates do (Fe···Fe 2.7 Å). The physical properties of this framework material indicate class II mixed-valence behavior in the Robin−Day classification scheme.

metadata.title: Intensely Colored Mixed-Valence Iron(II) Iron(III) Formate Analogue of Prussian Blue Exhibits Néel N-Type Ferrimagnetism
